contentrichtext.text: {{Unreferenced|date=July 2009}} In [[physics]], a '''quiver diagram''' is a graph representing the [[matter]] content of a [[gauge theory]] that describes [[D-branes]] on [[orbifold]]s. Each node of the graph corresponds to a factor [[unitary group|''U''(''N'')]] of the [[gauge group]], and each link represents a field in the [[bifundamental representation]] :<math>(M,\bar{N})</math>. The relevance of quiver diagrams for [[string theory]] was pointed out and studied by [[Michael R. Douglas|Michael Douglas]] and Greg Moore.<ref>D-branes, Quivers, and ALE Instantons http://arxiv.org/abs/hep-th/9603167</ref> While string theorists use the words ''quiver diagram'', many of their colleagues in [[particle physics]] call these diagrams ''mooses''. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==See also== *[[quiver (mathematics)]]. [[Category:Theoretical physics]] {{physics-stub}}
